cards.title: Promotion of Active Learning
cards.content: The main goal was to establish an interactive platform that enables individuals to immerse themselves in a journey of active learning, driven by hands-on exercises.

cards.title: Supporting Fellow Learners
cards.content: The core purpose was to offer a valuable hub for all those seeking effective, self-directed education, providing guidance and resources to diverse learners.

cards.title: Hands-On Coding
cards.content: Experience Lightning Network by typing and executing actual code with syntax highlighting

cards.title: Engaging Experience
cards.content: Our passion lies in creating an immersive, understandable learning journey.

cards.title: Igniting Curiosity
cards.content: By granting free access and content suitable for learners of varying proficiency levels, the ambition was to ignite curiosity and enthusiasm for continuous learning.

list.title: A Spectrum of Cool Subjects
list.content: Through our "type and execute code yourself" approach, you'll immerse yourself in practical and interactive learning. Engage with real-time exercises for a deeper understanding.

list.title: Hands-On Experience
list.content: LightningLearn offers a complete learning immersion. Engage in tasks, challenges, lessons, and quizzes that refine your Lightning Network skill

list.title: Real-time Practice Access
list.content: We offer the opportunity to work on real-time exercises and simulations. This allows you to directly apply your knowledge and experience Lightning Network in a secure environment.

implementations.content: is a lightweight, highly customizable and standard compliant implementation of the Lightning Network protocol.

implementations.title: Eclair
implementations.content: Eclair (French for Lightning) is a Scala implementation of the Lightning Network.

implementations.title: The Lightning Network Daemon
implementations.content: is a complete implementation of a Lightning Network node. lnd has several pluggable back-end chain services including btcd (a full-node), bitcoind, and neutrino (a new experimental light client)

steps.Step 1:
Run the following command to clear the terminal:
clear
steps.Step 2:
Install the snapd package using the following command:
sudo apt-get install snapd -y
steps.Step 3:
Install the bitcoin-core client using snap:
sudo snap install bitcoin-core
steps.Step 4:
Create a symbolic link to access Bitcoin Core binaries:
sudo ln -s /snap/bitcoin-core/current/bin/bitcoin{d,-cli} /usr/local/bin/
steps.Step 5:
Clone the Lightning Network repository from GitHub:
git clone https://github.com/ElementsProject/lightning.git
steps.Step 6:
Update the system and then install necessary packages for compilation:
 sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get install -y autoconf automake build-essential git libtool libsqlite3-dev python3 python3-pip net-tools zlib1g-dev libsodium-dev gettext pip3 install --upgrade pip pip3 install --user poetry
steps.Step 8:
Configure and compile the Lightning Network source code:
. /configure --enable-developer && make -j7 && make install
steps.Step 9:
Create a directory to store Bitcoin data:
mkdir ~/.bitcoin
steps.Step 10:
Run the script to start a Bitcoin regtest network:
. contrib/startup_regtest.sh
steps.Step 11:
Start the Lightning Network daemon with 2 nodes:
start_ln 2
steps.Step 12:
Generate 10 blocks in the Bitcoin regtest blockchain:
bt-cli generatetoaddress 10 $(bt-cli getnewaddress)
steps.Step 13:
Get the balances of Bitcoin addresses:
bt-cli getbalances
steps.Step 14:
Get information about the Lightning Network node:
l2-cli getinfo
steps.Step 15:
Connect to the first Lightning Network node:
l1-cli connect 027530d124566d735277cf74dd030b7ef6fba8f671e67ecd48075827989d977600@127.0.0.1:7272
steps.Step 16:
List the connected peers of the first node:
l1-cli listpeers
